title: Synthetic Recap
body:
GOLDEN STATE (AP) — He didn’t just beat the Golden State Warriors. He conquered them. In a stunning, virtuoso performance that will echo through the annals of the league, Chris Webber authored a masterpiece, pouring in a career-high 44 points to will the Washington Bullets to a 110-102 road victory in 1997.

From the opening tip, this was Webber’s stage. He was an unstoppable force, a blend of brute power and finesse that the Warriors had no answer for. Every spin move in the post, every face-up jumper, and every authoritative drive to the rim was a statement. He didn't just score; he dominated, finishing with a staggering 44 points on 57% shooting, a testament to his offensive efficiency against a helpless defense.

While Webber’s scoring was historic, his all-around game was equally formidable. He hauled in 15 rebounds, controlled the paint, and dished out 5 assists, proving he was the complete engine of the Bullets’ attack. Juwan Howard provided crucial support with 21 points, but this night was a solo concerto.

The Warriors, led by Joe Smith’s 21 points, fought valiantly but were ultimately spectators to a singular, career-defining event. In the closing minutes, as the outcome was sealed, the only remaining question was the final tally next to Webber’s name. When the horn sounded on his 44-point tour de force, it was clear the basketball world had witnessed something special—a night where one man, through sheer force of will, carved his name into the record books and carried his team to victory.
